content.raw: Food for thought; this is basically generating code, not APIs (that's why it has to be included once and only once).  We could make the script output to a `.cc` file, then `#include` the `.cc` file.  It's kind of ugly, but it's a good indicator that something odd is going on and shouldn't be used elsewhere.  That being said, I don't feel strongly about it, so leaving it as a `.hh` is fine as well.
content.html: Food for thought; this is basically generating code, not APIs (that's why it has to be included once and only once). We could make the script output to a .cc file, then #include the .cc file. It's kind of ugly, but it's a good indicator that something odd is going on and shouldn't be used elsewhere. That being said, I don't feel strongly about it, so leaving it as a .hh is fine as well.

content.raw: I added a header guard, so people can include it multiple times without danger. [19b571f](#!/osrf/sdformat/commits/19b571fb77b737eefca52e6ba3192897ab7e1aca?at=default)
content.html: I added a header guard, so people can include it multiple times without danger. 19b571f

content.raw:
I've got two overall questions about this:

1.  Does this structure of a map-within-a-map resolve the difficulties we had talked about earlier about XML files that include other XML files?
2.  Does this handle the conversions in `Converter.cc` as well?  The tests there are a little weaker than they should be, so I just want to check that it works for those cases.
content.html:
I've got two overall questions about this:

  1. Does this structure of a map-within-a-map resolve the difficulties we had talked about earlier about XML files that include other XML files?
  2. Does this handle the conversions in Converter.cc as well? The tests there are a little weaker than they should be, so I just want to check that it works for those cases.

content.raw:
It handles #1 because the `init` functions in [parser.cc](http://parser.cc) use the map.

It doesn’t handle the converter. I can do that in a separate pull request.
content.html:
It handles #1 because the init functions in parser.cc use the map.

It doesn’t handle the converter. I can do that in a separate pull request.

content.raw:
Can we replace the Ruby script with a Python script to simplify downstream consumption? I would like to avoid needing to either (a) incorporate Ruby into our build process or (b) have to reduplicate this logic downstream if possible.

Patch on latest commit: https://github.com/EricCousineau-TRI/sdformat/commit/4bad9c20555a7350e46f629e7a0fb5222a4260f1

Related downstream discussion: https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/issues/7874#issuecomment-391777957
content.html:
Can we replace the Ruby script with a Python script to simplify downstream consumption? I would like to avoid needing to either (a) incorporate Ruby into our build process or (b) have to reduplicate this logic downstream if possible.

Patch on latest commit: https://github.com/EricCousineau-TRI/sdformat/commit/4bad9c20555a7350e46f629e7a0fb5222a4260f1

Related downstream discussion: https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/issues/7874#issuecomment-391777957

content.raw:
We use ruby extensively in the OSRF simulation team, and I personally am not super familiar with python. This change would have negative impacts. 

Also, changing an upstream package to fit the build system of a downstream package is a bit odd and strikes me as a bad practice.
content.html:
We use ruby extensively in the OSRF simulation team, and I personally am not super familiar with python. This change would have negative impacts.

Also, changing an upstream package to fit the build system of a downstream package is a bit odd and strikes me as a bad practice.

content.raw: I don’t think it is bad practice to provide support to downstream users? I believe @eacousineau provided a working patch. Would it be too difficult to incorporate this patch here? would it break anything?
content.html: I don’t think it is bad practice to provide support to downstream users? I believe @eacousineau provided a working patch. Would it be too difficult to incorporate this patch here? would it break anything?

content.raw:
This particular case is troubling because a downstream user should not care about a script that is not distributed and is only used at configuration time. 

Bazel breaks standard software distribution practices \(ie a software package should not internalize and build all of its dependencies\), and I’m morally opposed to supporting that behavior. If a downstream user wants to follow uncommon development practices, then the burden is on them to handle the consequences.
content.html:
This particular case is troubling because a downstream user should not care about a script that is not distributed and is only used at configuration time.

Bazel breaks standard software distribution practices (ie a software package should not internalize and build all of its dependencies), and I’m morally opposed to supporting that behavior. If a downstream user wants to follow uncommon development practices, then the burden is on them to handle the consequences.

content.raw: Maybe so, I’m not the most qualified person to discuss this with. All I know is that this alone does not fix our \(yes downstream\) problem [7874](https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/issues/7874). Besides a matter of style or moral issues between ruby/python, cmake/bazel \(and why not to throw Emacs/vim :slight_smile: , they always seem to be in this kind of discussions\), is it too bad of an idea to support the python approach for those of us who switched to the dark side of the force? maybe if the ruby interpreter is not available make use of the python script?
content.html: Maybe so, I’m not the most qualified person to discuss this with. All I know is that this alone does not fix our (yes downstream) problem 7874. Besides a matter of style or moral issues between ruby/python, cmake/bazel (and why not to throw Emacs/vim , they always seem to be in this kind of discussions), is it too bad of an idea to support the python approach for those of us who switched to the dark side of the force? maybe if the ruby interpreter is not available make use of the python script?
